com.artisan.activity

Class ArtisanActivity

  • java.lang.Object
    • android.content.Context
      • android.content.ContextWrapper
        • android.view.ContextThemeWrapper
          • android.app.Activity
            • com.artisan.activity.ArtisanActivity
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    android.content.ComponentCallbacks, android.content.ComponentCallbacks2, android.view.KeyEvent.Callback, android.view.LayoutInflater.Factory, android.view.LayoutInflater.Factory2, android.view.View.OnCreateContextMenuListener, android.view.Window.Callback, ArtisanBoundActivity

    public class ArtisanActivity
extends android.app.Activity
implements ArtisanBoundActivity

    Use this class to add Artisan to your app. Every Activity needs to extend from ArtisanActivity or be configured to call all of our utility methods so that we can provide you with real-time experiments, optimizations, personalizations and analytics.

    If you choose not to extend ArtisanActivity (or are already extending another activity) you will need to do the following for each activity in your app:

    • implement the interface ArtisanBoundActivity
    • add an implementation for the interface method public ArtisanService getArtisanService()
    • add an implementation for onCreate, onStart, onStop and onDestroy and call our utility methods
    • add custom implementations of each version of setContentView that you are using that calls one of the versions of artisanSetContentView

    Sample usage for an Activity that does NOT extend ArtisanActivity: 

     package com.example.sampleapp;
 
 import android.app.Activity;
 import android.os.Bundle;
 import android.view.View;
 
 import com.artisan.activity.ArtisanActivity;
 import com.artisan.services.ArtisanBoundActivity;
 import com.artisan.services.ArtisanService;
 
 public class SampleActivity extends Activity implements ArtisanBoundActivity {
 
        @Override
        protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
                super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
                // Call Artisan AFTER super onCreate
                ArtisanActivity.artisanOnCreate(this);
                setContentView(R.layout.activity_sample_layout);
        }
 
        @Override
        protected void onStart() {
                super.onStart();
                // Call Artisan AFTER super onStart
                ArtisanActivity.artisanOnStart(this);
        }
 
        @Override
        protected void onStop() {
                super.onStop();
                // Call Artisan AFTER super onStop
                ArtisanActivity.artisanOnStop(this);
        }
 
        @Override
        protected void onDestroy() {
                // Call Artisan method BEFORE onDestroy
                ArtisanActivity.artisanOnDestroy();
                super.onDestroy();
        }
 
        @Override
        public void setContentView(int layoutResID) {
                View view = ArtisanActivity.artisanGetContentView(layoutResID, this);
                super.setContentView(view);
        }
 
        @Override
        public void setContentView(View view) {
                View contentView = ArtisanActivity.artisanGetContentView(view, this);
                super.setContentView(contentView);
        }
 
        @Override
        public void setContentView(View view, LayoutParams params) {
                View contentView = ArtisanActivity.artisanGetContentView(view, params, this);
                super.setContentView(contentView);
        }
 
        @Override
        public ArtisanService getArtisanService() {
                return ArtisanActivity._getArtisanService();
        }
 }
    Since:
    Artisan 2.0.18

      • artisanOnCreate

        public static void artisanOnCreate(android.app.Activity activity)

        If you choose not to extend the ArtisanActivity class for your own activities then you will need to add an implementation for onCreate and call this method after you call super.onCreate.

        Sample usage: 

         @Override
 protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
        // Call Artisan AFTER super onCreate
        super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
        ArtisanActivity.artisanOnCreate(this);
 }
        Parameters:
        activity - the Activity that is being created

      • artisanOnStart

        public static void artisanOnStart(android.app.Activity activity)

        If you choose not to extend the ArtisanActivity class for your own activities then you will need to add an implementation for onStart and call this method after you call super.onStart.

        Sample usage: 

         @Override
 protected void onStart() {
        super.onStart();
        // Call Artisan AFTER super onStart
        ArtisanActivity.artisanOnStart(this);
 }
        Parameters:
        activity - a reference to the activity that is being started

      • artisanOnStop

        public static void artisanOnStop(android.app.Activity activity)

        If you choose not to extend the ArtisanActivity class for your own activities then you will need to add an implementation for onStop and call this method after you call super.onStop.

         @Override
 protected void onStop() {
        super.onStop();
        // Call Artisan AFTER super onStop
        ArtisanActivity.artisanOnStop(this);
 }
        Parameters:
        activity - a reference to the activity that is being stopped

      • artisanOnDestroy

        public static void artisanOnDestroy()

        If you choose not to extend the ArtisanActivity class for your own activities then you will need to add an implementation for onDestroy and call this method before you call super.onDestroy

        Sample usage: 

         @Override
 protected void onDestroy() {
        // Call Artisan method BEFORE onDestroy
        ArtisanActivity.artisanOnDestroy();
        super.onDestroy();
 }

      • artisanGetContentView

        public static android.view.View artisanGetContentView(int layoutResID,
                                      android.app.Activity activity)

        If you choose not to extend the ArtisanActivity class for your own activities then you will need to add an implementation for at least one version of setContentView and call ArtisanActivity.artisanSetContentView and pass the resulting view to your call to super

        Sample usage: 

         @Override
 public void setContentView(int layoutResID) {
        View contentView = artisanSetContentview(layoutResID, this);
        super.setContentView(contentView);
 }
        Parameters:
        layoutResID - your layout's id. Artisan will inflate this and set it as the content view.
        activity - your activity
        Returns:
        the view that you should pass to super.setContentView(View view)

      • artisanGetContentView

        public static android.view.View artisanGetContentView(android.view.View view,
                                      android.app.Activity activity)

        If you choose not to extend the ArtisanActivity class for your own activities then you will need to add an implementation for at least one version of setContentView and call ArtisanActivity.artisanSetContentView and pass the resulting view to your call to super

        Sample usage: 

         @Override
 public void setContentView(View view) {
        View contentView = artisanSetContentview(view, this);
        super.setContentView(contentView);
 }
        Parameters:
        view - your content view
        activity - your activity
        Returns:
        the view that you should pass to super.setContentView(View view)

      • artisanGetContentView

        public static android.view.View artisanGetContentView(android.view.View view,
                                      android.view.ViewGroup.LayoutParams params,
                                      android.app.Activity activity)

        If you choose not to extend the ArtisanActivity class for your own activities then you will need to add an implementation for at least one version of setContentView and call ArtisanActivity.artisanSetContentView and pass the resulting view to your call to super

        Sample usage: 

         @Override
 public void setContentView(View view, LayoutParams params) {
        View contentView = artisanSetContentview(view, params, this);
        super.setContentView(contentView);
 }
        Parameters:
        view - your content view
        params - your layout params. Artisan weill set these on your view
        activity - your activity
        Returns:
        the view that you should pass to super.setContentView(View view)

                               android.app.Activity activity)

      • alreadyHaveGestureOverlay

        public static boolean alreadyHaveGestureOverlay(android.view.View view)
        Nothing to see here: utility method for the Artisan AspectJ code. This can determine if the Artisan Gesture overlay has already been added to the view hierarchy. It is expected that the content view is passed in because we only search down the tree for the gesture overlay.
        Parameters:
        view - the screen's content view.

      • _getArtisanService

        public static com.artisan.services.ArtisanService _getArtisanService()

        If you choose not to extend the ArtisanActivity class for your own activities then you will need to implement ArtisanBoundActivity and that interface will require you to implement getArtisanService. ArtisanBoundActivity

        *

        Sample usage: 

         @Override
 public ArtisanService getArtisanService() {
        return ArtisanActivity._getArtisanService();
 }
        Returns:
        the Artisan Service. This isn't something that you will need in your own application.
